oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rising water, flood of 1937
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph shows rising floodwaters. In the water can be seen a partially submerged building and a crane. At left is a sandbag levee just above a railroad track. A water tank and electrical power lines are in the background. Written at bottom left is (G630P-105) (2-5-37-2P).

In 1937 the Cumberland, Tennessee, Ohio, and Mississippi Rivers flooded to create the worst disaster in American history to that date. In January 21.24 inches (156 trillion tons) of rain fell in a 12-state region. Governor Gordon Browning activated the Tennessee National Guard because of record flooding in East and Middle Tennessee. Volunteers, state highway patrolmen, WPA workers, volunteers, and the Red Cross helped with sandbagging, providing for refugees, and building temporary housing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New Deal, 1933-1939--Tennessee ; Floods; Natural disasters
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photo Section, 105th Observation Squadron
